div1.p: In The United States Ciruit Court, For the Ninth Juidicial Circuit, Western Division of the State of Washington, Northern Division.
In re. Parte: Turner Jackson, Petitioner. No. 1325.
In The United States Ciruit Court, For the Ninth Juidicial Circuit, Western Division of the State of Washington, Northern Division.
In re. Parte: Turner Jackson, Petitioner. No. 1325.

Comes now the United States and the United States Marshal, appellants in the above entitled proceeding, by said attorney, Jesse A Frye, United States Attorney for the Western District of Washington, and in connection with said appeal herein, say: That in record and proceedings in the above entitled matter, and in the order and judgement rendered and entered herein on the 11th day of September 1905, there is manifest error, in this to wit:
I. That Court erred in finding that the petitioner, Turner Jackson, was wrongfully restrained of his liberty,
II. The Court erred in finding that the petitioner, Turner Jackson, was unlawfully held in custody by the United States Marshal for the Western District of Washington.
III. The Cout erred in holding and finding that the petitioner, Turner Jackson, was unlawfully held in custody by the Warden of the United States Penitentiary on McNeil's Island, Washington.
IV. The Cout erred in holding and finding that the terms of imprisonment of the petitioner, Turner Jackson, had expried as provided by law.
V. The Court erred in ordering and adjusting that the petitioner, Turner Jackson, was entitled to be dis- charged from the cusotdy of the United States Marshal.
VI. The Court erred in ordering and directing the United States Marshal for the Western District of Washington to discharge said Turner Jackson from custody and imprisonment/
VII. The Court erred in ordering and directing that the petitoner, Turner Jackson, be discharged from the United States penitentiary on McNeil's Island.
VIII. The Court erred in ordering the petitioner, Turner Jackson to be released from the custody of the officers of the United States.
IX. The Court erred in releasing and discharging the petitioner from the custody of the officers of the United States and restoring him to liberty.

X. The Court erred in entering the order and judgement of date of September 11, 1905 in the premises, dis- charging the petitioner, Turner Jackson, from the custody of the United States officers and restoring him to his liberty, for the reason that said order and judgement is not supported by the law in the premises, adn that said order and judgement of discharge is contrary to the facts in the premises, and that said order and judgement of discharge is not warranted, nor supported by the facts, nor the law in the premises, and that said judg- ement and order of discharge is contrary to law.

Wherefore, the United Stated Marshal for the Western District of Washington, and the United States of America, Appellants, pray: that their assignment of errors be entered upon the record in this proceeding; and they further pray that upon the hearing of this appeal it may be adjudged by the United Sates Circuit Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, that the order and judgement in this proceeding entered on the 11th day of September 1905, be in all things reversed and set aside, and in all things held for naught, and that the petitioner, Turner Jackson, be remanded to the custody of the United States Marshal for the Western District of Washington, and that he may be imprisoned in the United States Penitentiary on McNeil's Island, State of Washington, and there held until his term of sentence expires according to law.
Jesse A Frye, United States Attorney and Attorney for Appelants.
